description: Creates a new table from a table in an Amazon Redshift cluster snapshot. You must create the new table within the Amazon Redshift cluster that the snapshot was taken from. You cannot use RestoreTableFromClusterSnapshot to restore a table with the same name as an existing table in an Amazon Redshift cluster. That is, you cannot overwrite an existing table in a cluster with a restored table. If you want to replace your original table with a new, restored table, then rename or drop your original table before you call RestoreTableFromClusterSnapshot. When you have renamed your original table, then you can pass the original name of the table as the NewTableName parameter value in the call to RestoreTableFromClusterSnapshot. This way, you can replace the original table with the table created from the snapshot. You can't use this operation to restore tables with interleaved sort keys.

parameters.name: ClusterIdentifier
parameters.description: The identifier of the Amazon Redshift cluster to restore the table to.

parameters.name: SnapshotIdentifier
parameters.description: The identifier of the snapshot to restore the table from. This snapshot must have been created from the Amazon Redshift cluster specified by the ClusterIdentifier parameter.

parameters.name: SourceDatabaseName
parameters.description: The name of the source database that contains the table to restore from.

parameters.name: SourceTableName
parameters.description: The name of the source table to restore from.

parameters.name: NewTableName
parameters.description: The name of the table to create as a result of the current request.

nested_items.name: TableRestoreStatus
nested_items.description: Describes the status of a  RestoreTableFromClusterSnapshot operation.

nested_items.name: TableRestoreRequestId
nested_items.description: The unique identifier for the table restore request.

nested_items.name: Status
nested_items.description: A value that describes the current state of the table restore request.

nested_items.name: Message
nested_items.description: A description of the status of the table restore request. Status values include SUCCEEDED, FAILED, CANCELED, PENDING, IN_PROGRESS.

nested_items.name: RequestTime
nested_items.description: The time that the table restore request was made, in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC).

nested_items.name: ProgressInMegaBytes
nested_items.description: The amount of data restored to the new table so far, in megabytes (MB).

nested_items.name: TotalDataInMegaBytes
nested_items.description: The total amount of data to restore to the new table, in megabytes (MB).

nested_items.name: ClusterIdentifier
nested_items.description: The identifier of the Amazon Redshift cluster that the table is being restored to.

nested_items.name: SnapshotIdentifier
nested_items.description: The identifier of the snapshot that the table is being restored from.

nested_items.name: SourceDatabaseName
nested_items.description: The name of the source database that contains the table being restored.

nested_items.name: SourceSchemaName
nested_items.description: The name of the source schema that contains the table being restored.

nested_items.name: SourceTableName
nested_items.description: The name of the source table being restored.

nested_items.name: TargetDatabaseName
nested_items.description: The name of the database to restore the table to.

nested_items.name: TargetSchemaName
nested_items.description: The name of the schema to restore the table to.

nested_items.name: NewTableName
nested_items.description: The name of the table to create as a result of the table restore request.
